user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_count_sem_prop_t *count_prop)
{
    int                                 sval;
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_getvalue(&impl->id, &sval) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /* put the info into the structure */
    count_prop->value = sval;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl:
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t id;
} OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    int32     value;
} OS_count_sem_prop_t
...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.14 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token); does not call memcmp or perform any string comparison. Therefore it does not violate Rule 21.14. (A concrete violation would be e.g. using memcmp to compare two null-terminated strings, such as memcmp(s1, s2, strlen(s1)+1) or memcmp(s1, s2, n) instead of using strcmp/strncmp.)
